relationships.evidence_text: her mother Jehenne had been executed for the same crime
her father had been a maréchal of Raon
had lost small son Demenge aged some 16 weeks
death of his small son aged 9 months
her small son had recently been ill
house of her sister, wife of Jean Marond
Nicolas de Leusse, who was disputing over money with her husband

economic_context.details: Husband sold their house in the faubourg, which upset Annon and led to her seduction by the devil - she feared he would spend the money instead of turning it to profit. Nicolas de Leusse was disputing over money with her husband. Accused had many children to provide for. Could not afford to buy meat from butcher Mongeon Failley. Wife of Demenge Lucas came to complain about overtaxation of aides. Accused killed one of her own pigs to make it seem they had misfortunes like others. Nicolas de Leusse had been good to her in taking one of her children into his house, suggesting economic hardship requiring others to care for her children.

harms_catalog.precipitating_quarrel: to try powder; had 'deliberate will' but 'no hatred or enmity' - experimental malefice
to try powder; had 'deliberate will' but 'no hatred or enmity' - experimental malefice

harms_catalog.time_between_quarrel_and_harm: died some 2 weeks later (c. 3 years earlier, 1612)

material_culture.context: magical powder given by her master (devil Mre Navel) for maleficia; later gave her more powder; claimed to have thrown rest away

agreed to give her master a hen every year in order to be dispensed from sabbat attendance

feared husband would spend money from house sale instead of turning it to profit; had no money for meat; dispute with Nicolas de Leusse over money; devil promised her money
at sabbat all were masked so she recognised no-one

legal_context.imprisonment_conditions: Was in prison when she appeared for voluntary confession, since Demenge Polier had constituted himself partie civile against her

emotional_state_notes: appeared voluntarily to confess at her own request
felt pity for Gabriel Mercier and cured him

refused to kill husband despite master's urging (pointed out she had many children to provide for)
refused to kill wife of neighbor Humbert Bastien (objected that she was a good neighbour and had done her no harm)
refused to kill Nicolas de Leusse (objected that he had been good to her in taking one of her children into his house)
was beaten by her master for refusing to kill
claimed to have thrown rest of powder away
cured some victims after initially harming them (Gabriel Mercier, Toussaint Piernille Charier)

extraction_metadata.notes: This is an exceptionally detailed voluntary confession case with significant research value. KEY FEATURES: (1) VOLUNTARY CONFESSION: Annon appeared before judges at her own request to make full confession - extremely rare. She was already in prison because Demenge Polier had constituted himself partie civile, claiming she had long been reputed a witch. (2) MATERNAL INHERITANCE: Her mother Jehenne was previously executed for witchcraft, establishing intergenerational pattern. (3) ECONOMIC HARDSHIP AS SEDUCTION TRIGGER: The seduction occurred when upset about husband selling their house in faubourg - she feared he would spend money instead of turning it to profit. This economic anxiety was the emotional state when devil appeared. (4) POVERTY INDICATORS: Could not afford meat from butcher (leading to his death); had many children to provide for; Nicolas de Leusse had taken one of her children into his house (suggesting she couldn't support all); sent child to sister expecting help but they gave nothing; killed own pig 'so that they should be thought subject to misfortunes like others' (awareness of community suspicion). (5) MORAL AGENCY: She refused multiple times to kill people the devil suggested (husband, neighbor's wife, Nicolas de Leusse) and gave specific moral reasons based on family obligations and past kindness. This shows complex moral reasoning within the confession framework. (6) HEALING/CURING: She expressed pity and CURED some victims (Gabriel Mercier, Toussaint Piernille Charier); intended to cure Mongeon Failley but was arrested before she could. This suggests she saw herself as having healing powers, not just harming. Schema field 'practiced_healing' set to true with 'other' type. (7) EXPERIMENTAL MALEFICE: First two acts (wife of Jean Bietrix, cow) were explicitly 'to try powder' with 'deliberate will' but 'no hatred or enmity' - testing the powder's efficacy. (8) SABBAT NEGOTIATION: Only attended sabbat once, saw no one (all masked), then negotiated annual payment of hen to avoid future attendance - suggests some agency in relationship with devil. (9) BEATEN BY MASTER: Was beaten for refusing to kill - shows coercion within the diabolical pact. (10) RAPID TRIAL: Only 10 days from arrest (Oct 30) to execution (Nov 9). No torture used - confession was voluntary. (11) COSTS: 74 francs total, half falling on duchy. (12) TIMING: Arrest on Friday before All Saints (Oct 30, 1615) prevented her from curing the butcher who died same day - shows importance of timing in narrative. (13) WITNESSES: All 5 witnesses confirmed their harms, making this a well-corroborated case. (14) DYSENTERY OUTBREAK: Recent dysentery outbreak mentioned as context for one harm - shows epidemic disease context. (15) SOCIAL SLIGHTS: Multiple harms triggered by social slights (not invited to baptism, asked to move at veillée, sister gave nothing) showing importance of honor/inclusion. (16) VEILLÉE: Social gathering mentioned - important for understanding community social structures. (17) AIDES TAXATION: Wife of Demenge Lucas complained about overtaxation of aides - shows tax collection as source of conflict. (18) UNCERTAINTY RE CLAUDATTE'S CHILD: Confession says 'petit fils' (grandson) but witness testimony suggests it might be her son; I've recorded as son based on witness testimony saying 'small son' but noted the discrepancy. This could be translation/transcription issue or Claudatte was caring for grandson. Left as 'small son' in harms catalog to match witness testimony.
